summary: This document is an email chain from September 2019 between the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner (OCME) and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case. The discussion centers on a request from prosecutors for the OCME to destroy a specific draft interview report and to provide a list of documents they should not disclose, indicating post-mortem investigative coordination.

persons.name: Assistant United States Attorney
persons.context: The sender of the initial email on August 28, 2019, requesting the OCME destroy a draft FBI interview report and later discussing the provision of a non-disclosure list.

events.title: Draft FBI Interview Report Created
events.description: A draft interview report relating to the FBI's interview of an unspecified individual was created.

events.title: Prosecutor Requests Document Destruction
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney emails the OCME requesting they destroy their copy of the August 12 draft FBI interview report.

events.title: OCME Seeks Clarification on Non-Disclosure
events.description: An OCME representative renews a request for a specific list of documents the U.S. Attorney's Office wants withheld from disclosure and seeks to discuss the requested destruction.

locations.name: Office of Chief Medical Examiner
locations.context: The New York City agency involved in Epstein's autopsy and corresponding with federal prosecutors.

locations.name: New York, NY 10016
locations.context: The location of the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.

locations.name: Southern District of New York
locations.context: The U.S. Attorney's Office prosecuting the Epstein case.

keyFacts: Federal prosecutors requested the New York Chief Medical Examiner's office to destroy a draft report of an FBI interview dated August 12, 2019.
The OCME asked prosecutors to provide a specific list of documents they should not disclose, indicating ongoing legal coordination over evidence.
The email chain shows post-mortem investigative activity and evidence management discussions between agencies in late August and early September 2019.
The subject and recipient names in the emails are redacted, limiting identification of specific individuals involved in the correspondence.
